page.title: 20LLANSTEFFAN NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: The undulating landscape, with fields, dingles, woods, cliffs, dunes, saltmarsh and beach, provides a varied habitat for all sorts of flora and fauna, including some rarities. In the 1984/85 Estuary Bird count, 2 Brent Geese, an unusual species for this area, were seen. In summer 1985 a pair of Ringed Plover surprised bird watchers by successfully hatching two young from a nest on the beach despite constant disturbance by visitors. The heronry on Craig Ddu cliff had 19 occupied nests. Over 400 different species of wild plant have so far been identified in the tetrad around the village; recording goes on. The cliffs here are geologically interesting. The climate is relatively mild, wet and windy, with usually pleasant but unpredictable summers and the winters escaping the worst of the cold.
